line_1: Was bound by Honour and by Oath:
I'll bind myself fast by an oath,
line_2: And I'll henceforth be loyal to both.

line_1: Has sworn by Sticks (the Poet's Oath,
line_2: And Dread of Dogs and Poets both)

line_1: Whose Air cries Arm! whose very Look's an Oath:
line_2: But here's the Captain, that will plague you both,

line_1: In him that swears, and him that fears an oath.
line_2: The pious motive's much the same in both,
And give me back my troth.

line_1: But, while the falt'ring damsel takes her oath,
line_2: Consents to wed, and so secures them both.

line_1: Much less transfix his feelings with an oath,
line_2: Nor frown, unless he vanish with the cloth. —

line_1: Which I thought good as any oath?
line_2: Where of thy word then is the troth,

line_1: For they had evidence on oath,
line_2: That would appear too hard for both.
